intro: Chamaesyce neopolycnemoides, commonly known as the creeping sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a low-growing herbaceous perennial with opposite, ovate to lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in clusters during the spring and summer months. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open, sunny habitats such as coastal dunes and disturbed areas. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems and a subject of interest in botanical studies.
